file_metadata.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]
file_metadata.title: A 3D Tissue Model of Traumatic Brain Injury with Excitotoxicity That Is Inhibited by Chronic Exposure to Gabapentinoids

chunks.text: Injury progression associated with cerebral laceration is insidious. Following the initial trauma, brain tissues become hyperexcitable, leading to further damage. Clinicians employ strategies to mitigate secondary brain injury; however, better screening tools are needed to expedite mechanistic studies and drug discovery for enhanced neural tissue protection, repair, and regeneration. This study presents a bioengineered cortical brain model of traumatic brain injury (TBI) exhibiting primary and secondary injury characteristics, including radiating cell death and increased glutamate release with excitotoxic features. DNA content and tissue function were normalized by high-concentration, chronic gabapentinoid administrations. Further experiments suggest the treatment effects were neuroprotective rather than regenerative, evidenced by drug-mediated decreases in cell excitability and no drug-induced proliferation. The TBI model demonstrates validity and can serve as a customizable platform to assess cell type contributions to TBI progression and screen anti-excitotoxic and pro-regenerative compounds.
chunks.chunk_summary: A novel bioengineered TBI model exhibits excitotoxic features and responds to chronic gabapentinoid treatment, suggesting neuroprotective effects.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Traumatic brain injuries (TBIs) are a major cause of hospitalization and death. Cerebral lacerations, often resulting from penetrating head injuries, are particularly challenging to treat, leaving cavities that hinder repair. Secondary brain injuries arise from chemical cascades at the wound site, with excitotoxicity, driven by increased interstitial glutamate, being a significant threat. Repeated depolarizations can lead to epileptogenesis, causing further lesions. TBIs accelerate brain atrophy, increasing the risk of dementia and other neurological consequences. Mitigating secondary injury is crucial for TBI treatment and potential brain injury reversal, but effective high-throughput screening models are lacking.
chunks.chunk_summary: TBIs, especially cerebral lacerations, cause significant damage through secondary injury mechanisms like excitotoxicity, leading to accelerated brain atrophy and increased risk of neurological issues.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Rodent TBI models demonstrate the anti-excitotoxic effects of NMDA receptor antagonists like ketamine, which inhibit spreading depolarization and prevent secondary injury and seizures by reducing Ca2+ influx.  Voltage-gated calcium channel (VGCC) blockers, including gabapentin (GBP) and pregabalin (PGB), have also shown promise in treating secondary brain injury. A valid TBI model should respond to treatments that reduce excitability and limit calcium influx.
chunks.chunk_summary: NMDA receptor antagonists and VGCC blockers show promise in treating secondary brain injury by reducing neuronal excitability and calcium influx.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Current TBI research relies heavily on costly and inefficient animal models. Tissue engineering offers a balance between in vivo and in vitro systems, maintaining complexity and translational relevance while increasing flexibility and cost-effectiveness.  Organotypic slice cultures, while predictive of in vivo observations, are inherently damaged during preparation, limiting their use as true controls. This study utilizes a previously engineered cortical brain model, adaptable for studying pathophysiology, to develop a laceration-based TBI model exhibiting excitotoxicity and responsive to in vivo TBI treatments like gabapentinoids.
chunks.chunk_summary: Tissue engineering provides a promising alternative to animal models for TBI research, and this study uses a bioengineered cortical brain model to develop a laceration-based TBI model.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: The 3D neural tissue model is fabricated using a previously established protocol involving seeding rat embryonic cortical cells within porous silk-fibroin scaffolds coated with poly-D-lysine. These scaffolds are then embedded in a collagen type-I hydrogel to simulate the extracellular matrix, allowing for neural network formation. The resulting construct is highly interconnected and tunable, enabling long-term in vitro studies and adaptation for various experimental protocols.
chunks.chunk_summary: Embryonic rat cortical cells are seeded in silk scaffolds and embedded in collagen hydrogel to create a 3D neural tissue model.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: The laceration injury is simulated by removing the central core of the neural tissue using biopsy punches of 2mm or 3mm diameter. The resulting void is filled with a cell-free collagen hydrogel cap to assess neurite regrowth. The 2mm punch removes only the central hydrogel, while the 3mm punch removes both hydrogel and the inner part of the silk scaffold containing cell bodies.  The extent of damage is then quantified.
chunks.chunk_summary: Laceration injury is simulated by removing the central core of the tissue using biopsy punches and filling the void with collagen hydrogel.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Gabapentin (GBP) and pregabalin (PGB) were chosen as treatments to mitigate excitotoxicity by blocking voltage-gated calcium channels (VGCCs) via the α2δ-1 subunit.  Two administration schedules were used: acute (24h exposure) and chronic (repeated administrations every 3 days for 10 days).  AP5, an NMDAR antagonist, was also used as a positive control to reduce Ca2+ influx.
chunks.chunk_summary: GBP, PGB, and AP5 were used to mitigate excitotoxicity by targeting VGCCs and NMDARs, with both acute and chronic administration schedules.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: DNA quantification was performed using a Quant-iT-PicoGreen dsDNA Assay kit. Samples were permeabilized, frozen, shredded, centrifuged, and the supernatant was analyzed for DNA concentration using a microplate reader. Data were background-corrected and standardized.
chunks.chunk_summary: DNA was quantified using a PicoGreen assay after permeabilizing, freezing, and processing the samples.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Glutamate quantification was performed using a colorimetric Glutamate Assay kit. Media served as both buffer and background. Standards were generated, and media samples were added to plates. A Reaction Mix was added, incubated, and absorbance was measured. Data were background-corrected and standardized to DNA concentration.
chunks.chunk_summary: Glutamate levels were measured using a colorimetric assay, with media serving as the background, and data were normalized to DNA concentration.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Immunocytochemistry was performed to visualize neurites. Samples were fixed, blocked, and incubated with primary (anti-ẞIII Tubulin) and secondary antibodies. Samples were then stained with DAPI and imaged using a confocal microscope. Images were processed in ImageJ to quantify neurite area.
chunks.chunk_summary: Immunocytochemistry with anti-ẞIII Tubulin and DAPI staining was used to visualize and quantify neurite area.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Live cell imaging was performed using Calcein AM to visualize cell viability. Samples were imaged using a Nikon Eclipse Ti2 Inverted Microscope System, and images were processed in NIS-Elements and ImageJ.
chunks.chunk_summary: Calcein AM and a Nikon microscope system were used for live cell imaging to assess cell viability.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Local field potentials (LFPs) were recorded to assess tissue function. Samples were placed in extracellular solution and maintained at 37°C. LFPs were recorded using a glass pipette electrode and an Axon Instruments system. Spike potentials were isolated and their frequencies computed.
chunks.chunk_summary: LFP recordings were used to assess tissue function, with spike potentials isolated and their frequencies calculated.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: An excitotoxicity assay was performed on 2D cortical monolayers. Cells were exposed to glutamate, NMDA, or vehicle, with or without GBP and PGB treatment, to assess neuroprotective effects.
chunks.chunk_summary: A 2D excitotoxicity assay using glutamate, NMDA, and GBP/PGB treatments was performed to assess neuroprotection.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Patch-clamp electrophysiology was performed to characterize the effects of GBP and PGB on neuronal excitability.  Neurons were exposed to drugs in acute and chronic conditions, and current steps were applied to induce action potentials and determine spike threshold.
chunks.chunk_summary: Patch-clamp electrophysiology was used to assess the impact of GBP and PGB on neuronal excitability in acute and chronic conditions.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]

chunks.text: Cell cycle analysis was performed using propidium iodide (PI) flow cytometry. Cells were fixed, labeled with PI, and analyzed using a flow cytometer. Cell cycle phases were gated and percentages of cells in each phase were calculated.
chunks.chunk_summary: PI flow cytometry was used to analyze cell cycle stages and determine the percentage of cells in each phase.
chunks.authors: ["Nicolas G. Rouleau1,2,3", "Mattia Bonzanni1,2,3", "Michael D. Ehrlich1,2", "Marian K. Hettiaratchi4", "Camila C. Roberge1", "William Rooney1", "Michael Levin4,5", "and David L. Kaplan1,2,3,*"]
